bibl.title: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Henry Rose Carter, October 29, 1924

div1.p: Rosenau comments on a chapter from Carter's book on yellow fever

div1.head: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Henry Rose Carter, October 29, 1924
div1.opener:
Book
Rosenan
HARVARD UNIVERSITY
MEDICAL SCHOOL
DEPARTMENT OF PREVENTIVE MEDICINE AND HYGIENE
Boston, Massachusetts.
October 29, 1924.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2122 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I read your “History of Yellow Fever,” being
the first half of Section III, in two major and three minor
sittings. I intended to read it at my leisure and take per-
haps several weeks to it, but finished it in a few days for
two reasons, (1) because I found it so interesting and (2)
because I feared that some untoward accident might happen to
the precious manuscript. I am therefore sending it back to
you by registered mail, carefully packed and sealed. I want
to say that I am very glad to have had the opportunity to read
it and appreciate the compliment implied in the fact that you
entrusted it to me. I wish we had more epidemiological stud-
ies done as thoughtfully and carefully. I am amazed at the
erudition, the work, the feat of memory and the impelling power
of logic which pervades the whole treatise.

As I read along, I made notes of whatever popped
into my head, and you will find them on slips of paper which I
have left between the leaves. Sometimes I made a comment which
you afterwards answered satisfactorily, but I left the comment
anyhow. You will note that I have no paper interleagued after
about the middle, because I felt entirely incompetent to pass
a judgment on Mayan gibberish. I take off my hat to any man who
is able not only to quote it in the original, but actually to
discuss its translation and probable meaning of words and sym-
bols. You show an extraordinary knowledge of history and geo-
graphy - I found myself in the position of a man running after
a train to catch up with you. I cannot help thinking that if
you had not been a great epidemiologist you would have been a
great historian. You bid fair to be both. I do not see where
you got the time and patience to read all those original records
and understand what they were about and to tell them with such
charm and good humor. The logic is irresistable and your con-
clusions must be accepted - there is no getting away from that.

I wonder whether you would care to say something more
about the possible Asiatic origin of yellow fever. My under-
standing is that Stegomyia mosquitoes are very prevalent in
the Philippines, China and the Hawaiian Islands, and that
this represents infectable territory. It has doubtless never
been infected, for these areas would very likely have become
permanent endemic foci. This is a phase of the subject any-
how with reference to the practical point, especially in view
of the possibility of carrying the infection to these parts.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, am best to La-u-ra
M J Rosenau
